Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Public Service System for Automated Protein Structure Predictions
Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Kansas Center for Research Inc. is awarded a grant by the NSF Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program to develop a public service system for automated and reliable protein structure prediction based on the I-TASSER method. Recent years' CASP experiments have seen significant progress on protein 3D structure prediction. Medium to high-resolution structures can be predicted by the state-of-the-art methodologies through the combination of comparative modeling, threading and ab initio modeling techniques. The high-resolution models can be used for the analysis of biochemical function of the molecules in cells and for virtual ligand screening. The algorithms will be further improved by combining the I-TASSER structure assemble method with the meta-server threading techniques. As a complement to the full-length I-TASSER modeling, a locally installed meta-threading server (LOMETS) will be developed for the generation of multiple threading alignments and spatial restraints. The improvements will significantly increase the capacity of the service system to serve for the community, and help improve the quality of the core algorithms which the server systems are based on. The educational activities of the award involve development of four courses in structural bioinformatics as part of a bioinformatics program at KU. The project will also develop outreach materials in protein sequence-structure-function principles and participate in an annual multicultural roadshow designed to recruit underrepresented students to KU.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project are to develop public service systems for automated protein structure prediction as well as to improve education in related areas in bioinformatics.

 

Following these goals, the PI’s lab has developed two on-line service systems, i.e. LOMETS (http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/LOMETS/) for threading-based protein template identifications, and I-TASSER (http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/) for full-length protein structure construction. Both of the modeling systems have been widely used by the community. In particular, the I-TASSER server has constructed full-length models of structure and function for more than 150,000 proteins as of August, 2013, which have been submitted by more than 39,000 scientists from 112 countries. Consequently, the two articles describing the I-TASSER server (BMC Bioinf 2008, Nat Prot 2010) have been cited more than 1500 times in scientific publications. A rough analysis on the Google citation data showed that nearly 80% of the citing articles are from the non-specialist, biological and medical communities, where many of them have used the I-TASSER models to guide protein function analysis, structure-based drug discovery, and the design of experimental mutagenesis studies; most of the rest of the citing articles are from computational biological/bioinformatics studies for further computational method developments. This data demonstrates that the structure modeling system developed here has generated an important impact on the community for facilitating biomedical research. To test the accuracy of structure predictions, the I-TASSER server participated in the community-wide CASP experiment, which has been organized every two years since 1994 and to examine the state-of-the-art of structure prediction methods. The I-TASSER server, developed under this project, was ranked as one of the most accurate methods for protein three-dimensional structure predictions in the last four CASP contests in 2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012. The standalone I-TASSER package has been released to the community for free download through the website of the PI’s lab.

 

The project has provided important opportunities for training and education in the University of Michigan. Multiple graduate and undergraduate students have been trained by fully or partially participating in the project; several of the students are from underrepresented communities including the African American and Pacific Islander communities. Four bioinformatics courses have been developed and taught in the Center for Bioinformatics at the University of Kansas and the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics at the University of Michigan. Meanwhile, the I-TASSER and LOMETS systems will keep running after the expiration of the project to continue to assist biological and medical studies, in agreement with its long-range goal of improving public health.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2013
Modified by: Yang Zhang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The major goals of this project are to develop public service systems for automated protein structure prediction as well as to improve education in related areas in bioinformatics. Following these goals, the PIÆs lab has developed two on-line service systems, i.e. LOMETS (http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/LOMETS/) for threading-based protein template identifications, and I-TASSER (http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/) for full-length protein structure construction. Both of the modeling systems have been widely used by the community. In particular, the I-TASSER server has constructed full-length models of structure and function for more than 150,000 proteins as of August, 2013, which have been submitted by more than 39,000 scientists from 112 countries. Consequently, the two articles describing the I-TASSER server (BMC Bioinf 2008, Nat Prot 2010) have been cited more than 1500 times in scientific publications. A rough analysis on the Google citation data showed that nearly 80% of the citing articles are from the non-specialist, biological and medical communities, where many of them have used the I-TASSER models to guide protein function analysis, structure-based drug discovery, and the design of experimental mutagenesis studies; most of the rest of the citing articles are from computational biological/bioinformatics studies for further computational method developments. This data demonstrates that the structure modeling system developed here has generated an important impact on the community for facilitating biomedical research. To test the accuracy of structure predictions, the I-TASSER server participated in the community-wide CASP experiment, which has been organized every two years since 1994 and to examine the state-of-the-art of structure prediction methods. The I-TASSER server, developed under this project, was ranked as one of the most accurate methods for protein three-dimensional structure predictions in the last four CASP contests in 2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012. The standalone I-TASSER package has been released to the community for free download through the website of the PIÆs lab. The project has provided important opportunities for training and education in the University of Michigan. Multiple graduate and undergraduate students have been trained by fully or partially participating in the project; several of the students are from underrepresented communities including the African American and Pacific Islander communities. Four bioinformatics courses have been developed and taught in the Center for Bioinformatics at the University of Kansas and the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics at the University of Michigan. Meanwhile, the I-TASSER and LOMETS systems will keep running after the expiration of the project to continue to assist biological and medical studies, in agreement with its long-range goal of improving public health.
